title: Top Asian Dividend Stocks To Consider In August 2025
description: As Asian markets navigate a complex landscape marked by evolving trade ties and fluctuating interest rates, investors are increasingly looking towards dividend stocks as a potential source of steady income. In this environment, selecting robust dividend-paying companies can offer stability and income generation, appealing to those seeking to balance growth with reliable returns.
content:
As Asian markets navigate a complex landscape marked by evolving trade ties and fluctuating interest rates, investors are increasingly looking towards dividend stocks as a potential source of steady income. In this environment, selecting robust dividend-paying companies can offer stability and income generation, appealing to those seeking to balance growth with reliable returns. Click here to see the full list of 1055 stocks from our Top Asian Dividend Stocks screener. Let's review some notable picks from our screened stocks. Overview: Dah Sing Banking Group Limited is an investment holding company that offers banking and financial services in Hong Kong, Macau, and the People's Republic of China, with a market cap of HK$14.83 billion. Operations: Dah Sing Banking Group Limited generates revenue primarily from Personal Banking (HK$3.16 billion), Treasury and Global Markets (HK$1.91 billion), Corporate Banking (HK$161.15 million), and Mainland China and Macau Banking (HK$346.31 million). Dah Sing Banking Group's dividend yield of 6.26% is slightly below the top quartile in Hong Kong, and its dividend history has been volatile despite recent increases, such as the interim dividend rising to HK$0.31 per share from HK$0.27 last year. While dividends are currently well-covered by a payout ratio of 43.9%, concerns exist over high bad loans (3.1%) and a low allowance for these loans (44%). Earnings growth is forecasted to decline slightly in the coming years, but recent earnings showed improvement with net income rising to HK$1.58 billion from HK$1.40 billion year-over-year for the half-year ending June 2025.
• Click here and access our complete dividend analysis report to understand the dynamics of Dah Sing Banking Group.
• In light of our recent valuation report, it seems possible that Dah Sing Banking Group is trading beyond its estimated value. Overview: BRC Asia Limited, with a market cap of SGD1.08 billion, is involved in the prefabrication of steel reinforcement for concrete across Singapore and various international markets including Australia, Brunei, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand, and India.

However, concerns exist over high bad loans (3.1%) and a low allowance for these loans are raised. The article also mentions BRC Asia Limited, a company involved in the prefabrication of steel reinforcement for concrete across Singapore and various international markets.

BRC Asia Limited, together with its subsidiaries, engages in the prefabrication of steel reinforcement for use in concrete in Singapore, Australia, Brunei, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand, India, and internationally. It operates through three segments: Fabrication and Manufacturing, Trading, and Others. The company is involved in the trading of steel reinforcing bars; and manufacture and sale of wire mesh fences.

Dah Sing Banking Group Limited, an investment holding company, provides banking, financial, and other related services in Hong Kong, Macau, and the People’s Republic of China. It operates Personal Banking, Corporate Banking, Treasury and Global Markets, Mainland China and Macau Banking, and Others segments. The company accepts deposits from individual customers and provides residential mortgage lending, personal loans, overdrafts, vehicle financing, and credit card services, as well as insurance and investment services.

argos_summary: Asian investors are turning to dividend stocks for steady income amid trade uncertainty and rate swings, and the article spotlights three picks. Dah Sing Banking Group (HK) offers a 6.26% yield with a solid payout ratio but faces higher bad‑loan risk and is slightly undervalued. BRC Asia (SG) delivers a 5.1% yield, strong earnings coverage, and trades well below its fair‑value estimate. Qingdao Hiron Commercial Cold Chain (CN) provides a 3.4% yield, growing dividends, yet its payment history is volatile and the stock is also trading beneath its intrinsic value.
